head: INEC is improving in administering elections.
sub: [motion graphic of INEC official at polling unit from the main page motioning a voter to step forward]
text: But the process could still be strengthened.

head: Comparing 2011 to 2015, 28% more polling units had INEC officials present by 7:30am on election day. Nationally, 70% of polling units were staffed at their assigned time in 2015.
text: From 2011 to 2015, INEC improved in staffing polling units on time in southern states.

head: In 2011 and 2015, INEC tried to prevent double voting by separating accreditation and voting processes. While effective, there were still challenges, including around its universal implementation.
sub: In 2016, INEC adopted a process that once again combined accreditation and voting.

head: INEC officials continue to consistently ink fingers of voters as they are accredited. In 2011 and in 2015, officials in 96% of polling units marked most or all voter’s fingers with ink.

High levels of rejected ballots disenfranchise voters that intended to cast a ballot on election day. In 2011 according to PVT data for the presidential election, an estimated 3% of ballots were rejected. By 2015, it dropped to 2%.
sub: [static infographic of a person trying to cast a ballot frowning]
text: While a 1% difference may not seem like much, it meant that hundreds of thousands fewer voters’ ballots were rejected based on how they were completed.

head: While there is still room to improve, INEC has made measurable advancements in how they administer elections. A PVT will confirm whether this trend continues in 2019.
